Embleme 17. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Tower orbesorbs governegovern this worke of fire.

lg.l: Consult with Nature, and four orbes acquire,
Excited with a soft internall fire:
The first and lowest Vulcan doth declare,
Hermes the next, the third is Luna's Sphere,
PhæbusPhebus the fourth is thinethin and Natures fire.
By these young Students may to truth aspire.

div.head: Discourse 17.
div.ab:
The Philosophers have in many places made mention of four sorts of fire
necessary to the naturall worke, namely Lully, the Author of Scala, Ripley,
and many others: and to this end Raymund speaking of fires (Sayth Scala).
You must note, that here are contrary operations: because as the fire-
against nature dissolves the Spirit of a fixed body into the water of a-
cloud, and binds the body of a volatile spirit into a congealed earth, soeso></choice
contrarywisecontrariwise the fire of nature congealescongeals the dissolved spirit of a fixed
body into a globous earth, and resolves the fixed body of a volatile-
Spirit by fire against nature, not into the water of a cloud, but into Phi
losophicall water. Ripley speaks more clearly of these fires in gate 3. thus:
There are four sorts of fires, which you ought to know, the naturall, unna
turall, fire against nature, and elementall, which kindlethkindles wood: These
fires wee use, and noe more. Fire against nature ought to excruciate-
bodyes, that is the dragon, as I tell you, violently burning, as the fire of hell.
The fire of nature is the third menstruum, that fire is naturally in every
thing: Occasioned fire wee call unnaturall, as the heat of ashes and baths
to putrefy: Without these fires you can bring nothing to putrefaction, where
by your matter may be separated, that it may at once be proportioned-
for a new conjunction: Make therefore a fire within in your glasse, which
can burne bodyes more effectually, than elementall fire: these are their
sayings. They are indeed called fires, because they have a fiery virtue,-
the naturall in coagulating, the unnaturall in dissolving, the fire against
nature in corrupting, the elementall in administringadministering the first heat and
motion: And there is a concatenated order observed in them, that the Se
cond may be incited by the first, the third by the second, the fourth by
the third and first together to action, soeso></choice as that one is the agent, and
the other the patient, and the same both agent and patient in different
respect: That which is observed in iron rings or pillars held together by a
Magnet, and joyned by mutuall contact, the same in these fires: for the
elementall doth like the Magnet immit its virtue though the second
and third even to the fourth, and joynes one to another by mutuall-
operations, and causethcauses them to stickestick together, till internall action be
effected amongst the uppermost: The first is elementall fire indeed-
and name, the second is aire or airy, the third watry or of a Lunar na
ture, the fourth earthy: It is needlesseneedless to say any thing of the first,-
because it is knowne to every mans eye and touch: The three other are
dragons, menstrua's, waters, Sulphurs, and Mercuryes: Dragons, because-
being participants of venenosity, they devouredevour serpents of their owne
kind, frett and alter, that is, dissolve and coagulate bodyes incorporated-
and mixed with them: They are called Menstrua's, because the Philoso
phicall infant is produced from them, and nourished therewith even to
its nativity: Lully in his booke of the Quintessence, dist. 3. hath two-
Discourse 17.
Menstruums, the vegetable, and minerall, Ripley in his Præface of the gates hath
three, which are really one and doe agree: for the generation of the infant
is made of them alltogether, and a while water præceedspreceeds the birth of it, which
is not of the substance but superfluity of the infant, and therefore to be-
separated: They are waters, because in fire they ShewShow a watry nature, that
is, flowing and liquidity, which agrees with water: Manifest it is that the-
propertyesproperties of waters are different and wonderfull, whereof some doe petrefypetrify, be
ing coagulated into very hard stones fitt for building: Very like these are the-
Philosophers minerall waters, which doe condense, and turne into a stony con
sistence: They are allso called Sulphurs because of the virtue of Sulphur,-
which they comprehend in them, for the Sulphur of nature is mixed and-
made one with the other Sulphur, and the two Sulphurs are dissolved by one,
and one is separated from two, and the Sulphurs are præserved and contained
by Sulphur, as Yximidius in Turba sayth: Now what Sulphurs are Dardaris
there declares in these words: Sulphurs are Souls hidden in the fower elements,
which being extracted by art doe naturally containe one another and are-
joyned together: if you can by water governegovern and purify well that which-
is hidden in the belly of Sulphur, that hidden thing meeting with its owne-
nature rejoycethrejoices, even as water with its like. I will now tell you (Sayth Mosius
allso) what it is: the first indeed, which is fiery Argent vive, the second, the-
body compounded in it, and the third is the water of Sulphur, by which the
first is washdwashed, and dilacerated, and governed, till the worke be accomplished:
That which is sayd of Sulphurs, the same may be understood of soeso></choice-
many Mercuryes: For this sayth the same Mosius afterwards: Argent vive
Cambar is the Magnesia, but Argent vive or Auripigment is that Sulphur
which ascends from a mixd compound: But I will omittomit the inference of
more testimonyestestimonies, they being infinite and obvious to every man: These fourefour
fires are included as it were in Spheres and orbes, that is, every one hath a
particular center, from which or to which their motion tends, but neverthelesse
they are kept soeso></choice bound together partly by nature, partly by art, that one
can operate little or nothing without another, yea the action of one is the
passion of another, and on the contrary. . . . . . .
